image.altText: A boat moored by a small jetty with an orange fire burning in the background over the water.

props.synopsis: Authorities have issued an emergency warning as strong winds push the fire at Briagolong towards the Princes Highway.

title.children: Strong winds triple size of major bushfire as multiple blazes threaten communities in Victoria's east

image.altText: Fire viewed from Flaggy Creek

props.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with hundreds of firefighters battling multiple blazes in Victoria, while an emergency warning has been issued for Flinders Island in Tasmania’s north east. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in Victoria and Tasmania reach emergency level as residents told to keep watch

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Tasmania Fire Service says it's expecting volatile conditions on Flinders Island where an out of control bushfire has been burning since Sunday. An emergency level warning is in place for West End Road and the communities of Pine Scrub and Leeka. Residents who haven't evacuated already, are advised to leave immediately if it's safe to do so. The fire service says burning embers may threaten homes before the main fire arrives.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Out of control bushfire continues to burn on Flinders Island

featuredLink.title: Evacuation warning as emergency-level bushfire burns on Flinders Island

children.content: The Tasmania Fire Service says it's expecting volatile conditions on
where an out of control bushfire has been burning since Sunday.
Residents who haven't evacuated already, are
advised to leave immediately if it's safe to do so.
The fire service says burning embers may threaten homes before the main fire arrives.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are currently more than 600 firefighters battling to bring blazes burning in Victoria's Gippsland under control, as they prepare for strong winds and thunderstorms to hit the area later today. A fire at Briagolong tripled in size overnight as it continues to push towards the Princes Highway. There are three emergency warnings in place for the region. Country Fire Authority chief officer Jason Heffernan told News Breakfast the situation is continuing to change hour-by-hour. "We're experiencing spot fires well ahead of the main fire front and firefighters and doing their best to try and contain that fire but it is very challenging, recorded peak wind gusts of 80 km per hour is serving to be very difficult for firefighters on the ground," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hundreds of firefighters battling blazes in Victoria

featuredLink.title: Strong winds triple size of major bushfire as multiple blazes threaten communities in Victoria's east

image.altText: Split screen image of a woman and a man on ABC's Q+A.

props.synopsis: As Senator Malarndirri McCarthy reveals the moment she felt most "disempowered", a debate focused on who the Voice will help takes over Q+A.

title.children: 'Disadvantage' locked into the constitution or 'significant moment'? Voice debate heats up on Q+A

image.altText: woman standing in front of burnt house

props.synopsis: When the Saunders family made the decision to flee their east Gippsland home, they escaped with their pets and the clothes on their backs. They returned to find their "happy place" in ruins.

title.children: Lily's family home was her 'happy place'. A shock bushfire has them picking up the pieces

image.altText: a map of eastern australia showing hot temperatures for those parts

props.synopsis: The frequent spells of early spring heat resulted in Australia's third warmest September on record since 1910, with a national temperature 2.4C above the climatological average.

title.children: The heat won't stay: Temperatures to drop by as much as 20 degrees in 48-hours

image.altText: Landscape illustration of red earth, spinifex, tree silhouettes, sun rising and night sky with stars and clouds.

props.synopsis: On October 14, every Australian will be asked to answer a yes or no question. What you write on the ballot paper will determine whether our constitution is changed for the first time in more than four decades. Here's everything you need to know before you vote.

title.children: Your Voice voting cheat sheet: All your referendum questions, answered

image.altText: A young woman in a fluoro vest with pink glasses standing between trains.

props.synopsis: Chelsea Taylor thought university was the only option after school. But after three unfinished degrees and $30,000 in student debt, she felt "really, really lost" – until she became a train driver.

title.children: Lacklustre career advice in high schools limiting Australian teens, researcher says

image.altText: A silhouette of a man in profile. Behind him is a composite of images including a plane, a CCTV camera, police lights and a car.

props.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: 'X' went undercover to take down organised crime. He says he's been abandoned

image.altText: A girl sits up in bed, hugging her knees to her chest. Her face is blurred by a sheet of tempered glass.

props.synopsis: ABC Investigations has established more than 1,500 people have reported alleged sexual assaults and harassment in mental health wards over the past six years in Australia. It is launching a national crowdsourced investigation into mental health units and is asking people to share their experiences.

title.children: Parents of teenage girl considering legal action against Perth Children's Hospital after alleged rape in mental health ward

image.altText: An illustration shows several hands, arranged in a circle, holding sheets of paper marked with the Chinese flag.

props.synopsis: Australian law firms acting for the Chinese state are simultaneously completing work for the Australian government, raising concerns over sensitive work being done by those firms.

title.children: Beijing-owned businesses using Australian law firms to advise on takeovers of critical projects

image.altText: A bushfire and smoke seen in the distance from the top of a mountain on an island.

props.synopsis: A bushfire burning out of control on Flinders Island, north-east of Tasmania, is threatening two communities, with residents urged to evacuate.

title.children: Evacuation warning as emergency-level bushfire burns on Flinders Island

image.altText: Hands holding glasses give cheers, as confetti falls.

props.synopsis: As the government introduces draft legislation to tighten concessions for the largest superannuation account holders, new data reveals 11 more Australians have joined the ranks of account holders with more than $100 million in super.

title.children: Tax office reveals 11 more Australians reporting super balances of more than $100 million

image.altText: This photo shows the Microsoft Corp. logo outside a Microsoft Visitor Center

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Microsoft CEO says tech giants are competing for AI training content, Pope hints at allowing blessings for same-sex unions. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians who are unable to vote in the Voice referendu m on October 14, can now vote early anywhere in the country. From today, the following states and territories are open for early voters: Australian Capital Territory New South Wales Queensland South Australia Early voting opened on Monday for the following states and territories: Northern Territory Tasmania Victoria Western Australia You can read more on how to vote early here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Early referendum voting open for all of Australia

featuredLink.title: Early referendum voting starts today in half the country. Here's where to vote early and who's eligible

image.altText: A drone shot of a new housing estate, with houses stretching as far as the eye can see

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank is widely tipped to keep interest rates on hold when it meets today, but more hikes are expected later this year as 550,000 people come off fixed mortgages. The RBA itself warns that could put more people in financial stress, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: RBA set to keep rates on hold but many more Australians to soon hit breaking point

image.altText: An older couple sit side by side in a waiting room, in front of a large sign that says "Medicare Urgent Care Clinic".

props.synopsis: Less than half of the federal government's promised urgent care clinics have opened, months after the policy was supposed to be delivered.

title.children: Less than half of promised urgent care clinics have opened, and most are in Labor seats

image.altText: Trees in silhouette in front of a lightning strike.

props.synopsis: Tens of thousands of homes and businesses have been left without power across South Australia following a night of wild weather that included intense lightning and very strong wind gusts.

title.children: 'Lightning show' cuts power to thousands of properties across SA

image.altText: Taylor Adams in tears hugs Darcy Moore

props.synopsis: AFL premiership coach Craig McRae says all Collingwood players who featured during the season deserve medals after the club's grand final triumph.

title.children: 'It just seems wrong': More Magpies deserving of AFL Premiership medals says Cox, McRae

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Gorgon gas project on the coast of Western Australia.

props.synopsis: Australia may be a quarry to the world, and the mining of its natural resources might underpin our national budget. But we can and must demand better corporate ethics than this, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A 'sham' workforce in WA has exposed the shadowy ways of global oil and gas — and workers are paying the price

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

props.synopsis: The local share market is likely to fall sharply in morning trade as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the value of the Australian dollar, gold and oil suffered heavy losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX set to tumble, Australian dollar falls to 11-month low ahead of Reserve Bank decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! David Chau here, with your latest finance updates. The Australian share market is set to fall sharply this morning, with ASX futures down 1.4%. It looks like markets are increasingly accepting the possibility that interest rates could still rise in the coming months (which is bad for "riskier" assets like shares). However, the Reserve Bank is widely expected to keep its cash rate target on hold this afternoon, which will also be the first policy meeting chaired by new governor Michele Bullock. The Australian dollar also suffered heavy losses — it's down 1.1% to 63.6 US cents (near its weakest levels since November last year). That's after the US dollar jumped to an 11-month high. And that's because of a sell-off in the bond market, which has led to the US government's borrowing costs jumping to its highest level since October 2007 (around the time of the Global Financial Crisis). In particular, the US 10-year government yield climbed as high as 4.72%. (That's the return you'll get from lending your money to Uncle Sam for a decade — similar to a term deposit). Spot gold has also dropped 1.1% to $US1,827 an ounce, its lowest level in almost seven months. (Gold tends to do poorly when the US dollar rises). On oil markets, Brent crude futures plunged 1.8% to a three-week low of $US90.56 a barrel, as traders took advantage of a recent surge and cashed out. European stock markets also did poorly, with the Stoxx 600 index down 1%. Meanwhile, Wall Street fared better than everything else, with the Dow Jones down 0.2%, while the S & P 500 was flat, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.7%. This promises to be a very interesting day on markets. Stay tuned!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX futures down 1.4%, as Australian dollar falls to lowest level since November 2022

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in court and looks straight ahead. The gallery behind him is full of people.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump is fighting a civil lawsuit that could cost him control of his prized properties and his freedom to do business in New York. Here's what happened on day one of the trial.

title.children: With Trump Tower on the line, Trump's back in court to fight 'a corporate death penalty'. Here's how it's going

image.altText: A man and a woman wearing masks and formal clothing pose with clear glass trophies.

props.synopsis: Scientists Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman have won the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discoveries enabling the development of mRNA COVID-19 vaccines.

title.children: Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine awarded to scientists whose work enabled mRNA COVID-19 vaccines

image.altText: Firefighters use an extended ladder to reach up to an historic-looking building on fire.

props.synopsis: The Spanish nightclubs are understood to have been operating without a valid permit when 13 people were killed in a fire.

title.children: Spanish city previously ordered closure of nightclubs at centre of fatal fire

image.altText: Red dirt with mining equipment on top.

props.synopsis: Australia's first budget surplus in 15 years could prove fleeting amid forecasts the nation's resources earnings could plummet.

title.children: Australia's 'luck running out' as resources exports tipped to plunge in value

image.altText: Collage of Asian man with his adopted family, a photo of a Buddhist monk, and the man as a young monk.

props.synopsis: Jin-Gang-Dhyana is a branch of Buddhism with followers around the globe. But one man born into the spiritual community alleges it operates more like a cult, restricting contact with society and enforcing strict rules on the lives of some of its members.

title.children: Richard didn't go to school. He now believes he was raised in a cult

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

props.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages, and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation, and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear

image.altText: Close-up shot of Scales of Justice statue in Brisbane CBD on August 1, 2018.

props.synopsis: Accused rapists can be named by the media before they go to trial under new laws that come into effect in Queensland today. So, what will be different and what rights do accused people now have?

title.children: From today, accused rapists in Qld can be named by the media before they go to trial. Here's what's changing

image.altText: Houses under construction in the background with building materials in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A group of councils in the Loddon Mallee region is working to jointly appoint a dedicated regional housing officer, as part of a region-wide housing action plan.

title.children: Councils band together to tackle housing crisis crippling regional Victoria

image.altText: Message sign saying about koala deaths on Appin Road

props.synopsis: A wildlife rescue group says the NSW government needs to intervene to lower speed limits on a busy road south of Sydney where dozens of koalas have been killed by vehicle strikes.

title.children: 'Staggering' number of koala deaths prompts calls for lower speed limit on busy road

image.altText: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan addressing media outside a white building with Deputy Ben Carrol standing behind her

props.synopsis: Newly minted Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan has unveiled her cabinet less than a week after taking the state's top job.

title.children: Jacinta Allan unveils new cabinet as ex-IBAC chief issues fresh integrity warning

image.altText: Tourists swim at a vivid blue thermal pool in Mataranka.

props.synopsis: A lucrative water licence held by a station near Mataranka Hot Springs, which ignited a political scandal a decade ago, has never been used in full. But its new owners say they'll need the full amount for a new project.

title.children: Fears for popular hot springs as project could extract 2,300 Olympic pools of water a year

image.altText: A screenshot of a video game. A large red army is being approached by a small blue one. They're in a walled off area

props.synopsis: Scientists use Age of Empires to simulate ant warfare, with the aim of helping native ant species better fight their invasive counterparts.

title.children: How a classic computer game is giving native ants a fighting chance against invasive species

image.altText: A close up of a small rhinoceros calf standing on sand and with its head close to its approaching mother's.

props.synopsis: Indonesia's government says the rare Sumatran rhinoceros was born last week and stood up 45 minutes after her birth.

title.children: 'Happy news' as endangered Sumatran rhino, the smallest and hairiest species, is born in Indonesia
